author: Jo Øiongen
message: Do not KDE have a GUI solution for this? Seriously, I thought KDE did?

replies.author: Aurélien Gâteau
replies.message: KDE has a System Settings module to configure global shortcuts. It would be possible to use it to assign KSnapshot to another key, but this module cannot be used to reassign a key to another key (in my case, reassign "Print Screen" to "Menu"). The Xmodmap solution also has the advantage of being cross-desktop, so it also works when I am in my minimalist mood and run Openbox.

author: YoYo
message:
I got used to remapping kyes via setkeycodes, it affects directly what kernel reports for the keys, so is more 'syste wide' (works also on consoles and you can start X in ways that won't load user's xmodmap). It was also the only option for some keys/buttons on thinkpad tablets (some of them returned scancodes that were not mapped to anything...

Just find out the scancode and keycode you wish to map to each other (showkey -s, showkey -k, be sure to run it under console, not X), then put something like:

setkeycodes SCANCODE1 KEYCODE1 SCANCODE2 KEYCODE2....

into some script that would be run on startup (say /etc/local.d/setkeycodes.start on gentoo, not sure for other distros)

Snip from my old x41t configuration, which had forward/backward keys near cursor keys instead of pg up/down and didn't have a 'win' key (but had a '&<' key left of Z):

IBM_KEYS=(
# tablet keys
67 56 # Reset? (used as Alt)
6c 147 # Rotate
# 68 171 # Tools
68 157 # MyComputer, fluxbox doesn't react to XF86Tools, why?? so I use XF86MyCmp..
6b 1 # Esc
69 28 # Enter
#6b 56 # reset (used as Alt)
6d 103 # up
6e 108 # down (or reversed ;)

e06a 104 # Back/Forward -> PgUp/PgDown
e069 109
56 125 # Win instead of *&<
)
setkeycodes "${IBM_KEYS[@]}"

author: Rhys
message: Hi, I'd really like to do this on my thinkpad but I'm not as computer savvy as you. Could you post instructions for a less experienced user?

replies.author: Aurélien Gâteau
replies.message:
- Start a text editor such as Kate or Kwrite.
- Copy and paste the four lines I posted in.
- Save the file as .Xmodmap in your home folder.
- Log out and log back in. Should be good.

replies.author: Rhys
replies.message: It's a work laptop so I'm unable to download Kate or Kwrite and install. Can I use any windows based programme? Also, by home folder, do you mean direct to C:\

replies.author: Aurélien Gâteau
replies.message: Sorry, this workaround only works on X11-based system, not on Windows.
